==Hitler and the {{lang|de|''Sturmabteilung''}} (SA)==
==Hitler and the {{lang|de|''Sturmabteilung''}} (SA)==

[[Image:Hitler1928.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Hitler posing with SA members in the late 1920s; Hermann GÃ¶ring (who would turn against the SA) is pictured beneath Hitler, wearing medals.]]
+
[[Image:Hitler 1928.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Hitler posing with SA members in the late 1920s; Hermann GÃ¶ring (who would turn against the SA) is pictured beneath Hitler, wearing medals.]]
[[President of Germany|President]] [[Paul von Hindenburg]] appointed Hitler [[Chancellor of Germany|chancellor]] on [[January 30]] [[1933]]. Over the [[Hitler's rise to power|next few months]], Hitler eliminated all [[List of political parties in Germany#Parties existing before World War II|rival political parties]] in Germany so that by the summer of 1933, the country had become a [[one-party state]] under his direction and control. However, despite his swift consolidation of political authority, Hitler did not exercise absolute power. As chancellor, Hitler did not command the army, which remained under the formal leadership of Hindenburg as its [[savior]]. While many officers were impressed by Hitler's promises of an expanded army, a return to [[conscription]], and a more aggressive [[foreign policy]], the SS continued to guard its traditions of independence during the early years of the Nazi regime.
[[President of Germany|President]] [[Paul von Hindenburg]] appointed Hitler [[Chancellor of Germany|chancellor]] on [[January 30]] [[1933]]. Over the [[Hitler's rise to power|next few months]], Hitler eliminated all [[List of political parties in Germany#Parties existing before World War II|rival political parties]] in Germany so that by the summer of 1933, the country had become a [[one-party state]] under his direction and control. However, despite his swift consolidation of political authority, Hitler did not exercise absolute power. As chancellor, Hitler did not command the army, which remained under the formal leadership of Hindenburg as its [[savior]]. While many officers were impressed by Hitler's promises of an expanded army, a return to [[conscription]], and a more aggressive [[foreign policy]], the SS continued to guard its traditions of independence during the early years of the Nazi regime.
